senses.sense_definition: The official right or power to stop a decision, law, or plan from being accepted or put into action.

examples.text: The president has the power of <w>veto</w> over any legislation passed by congress.
Several members of the council threatened to use their <w>veto</w> to block the proposal.

senses.sense_definition: An official act of refusing to allow a law or decision to be made.

examples.text: The governor issued a <w>veto</w> to prevent the new tax bill from becoming law.
Legislators did not have enough votes to override the presidential <w>veto</w>.

senses.sense_definition: A strong prohibition or refusal given by someone in authority regarding a general matter.

examples.text: Her father put a strict <w>veto</w> on her staying out late with friends.
The manager's <w>veto</w> of the holiday party plan disappointed the entire staff.

senses.sense_definition: A mechanism or technique used in experiments to discard false positive results.

examples.text: The physics experiment utilized an active <w>veto</w> system to filter out cosmic ray interference.
Researchers designed a <w>veto</w> to ensure that background noise did not affect the data.

senses.sense_definition: To officially refuse to allow a law, decision, or plan to go ahead.

examples.text: The president <w>vetoed</w> the bill because he believed it would harm the economy.
Five permanent members of the council have the right to <w>veto</w> any resolution.

senses.sense_definition: To stop a plan or suggestion from happening by refusing to give permission.

examples.text: My parents <w>vetoed</w> my idea of taking a gap year before college.
We wanted to eat Italian food, but our friends <w>vetoed</w> the suggestion.
